trans-unit.source: In a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, *command elements* are the interactive UI elements that enable the user to perform actions, such as sending an email, deleting an item, or submitting a form.
trans-unit.target: In a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, *command elements* are the interactive UI elements that enable the user to perform actions, such as sending an email, deleting an item, or submitting a form.

trans-unit.source: This article describes the command elements, such as buttons and check boxes, the interactions they support, and the command surfaces (such as command bars and context menus) for hosting them.
trans-unit.target: This article describes the command elements, such as buttons and check boxes, the interactions they support, and the command surfaces (such as command bars and context menus) for hosting them.

trans-unit.source: Provide the right type of interactions
trans-unit.target: Provide the right type of interactions

trans-unit.source: When designing a command interface, the most important decision is choosing what users should be able to do.
trans-unit.target: When designing a command interface, the most important decision is choosing what users should be able to do.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you're creating a photo app, the user will need tools to edit their photos.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you're creating a photo app, the user will need tools to edit their photos.

trans-unit.source: However, if you're creating a social media app that happens to display photos, image editing might not be a priority and so editing tools can be omitted to save space.
trans-unit.target: However, if you're creating a social media app that happens to display photos, image editing might not be a priority and so editing tools can be omitted to save space.

trans-unit.source: Decide what you want users to accomplish and provide the tools to help them do it.
trans-unit.target: Decide what you want users to accomplish and provide the tools to help them do it.

trans-unit.source: For recommendations about how to plan the right interactions for your app, see [Plan your app](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh465427.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For recommendations about how to plan the right interactions for your app, see [Plan your app](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh465427.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Use the right command element for the interaction
trans-unit.target: Use the right command element for the interaction

trans-unit.source: Using the right elements for the right interactions can mean the difference between an app that feels intuitive to use and one that seems difficult or confusing.
trans-unit.target: Using the right elements for the right interactions can mean the difference between an app that feels intuitive to use and one that seems difficult or confusing.

trans-unit.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) provides a large set of command elements, in the form of controls, that you can use in your app.

trans-unit.source: Place commands on the right surface
trans-unit.target: Place commands on the right surface

trans-unit.source: You can place command elements on a number of surfaces in your app, including the app canvas (the content area of your app) or special command elements that can act as command containers, such as command bars, menus, dialogs, and flyouts.
trans-unit.target: You can place command elements on a number of surfaces in your app, including the app canvas (the content area of your app) or special command elements that can act as command containers, such as command bars, menus, dialogs, and flyouts.

trans-unit.source: Here are some general recommendations for placing commands:
trans-unit.target: Here are some general recommendations for placing commands:

trans-unit.source: Whenever possible, let users directly manipulate the content on the app's canvas, rather than adding commands that act on the content.
trans-unit.target: Whenever possible, let users directly manipulate the content on the app's canvas, rather than adding commands that act on the content.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the travel app, let users rearrange their itinerary by dragging and dropping activities in a list on the canvas, rather than by selecting the activity and using Up or Down command buttons.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the travel app, let users rearrange their itinerary by dragging and dropping activities in a list on the canvas, rather than by selecting the activity and using Up or Down command buttons.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, place commands on one of these UI surfaces if users can't manipulate content directly:
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, place commands on one of these UI surfaces if users can't manipulate content directly:

trans-unit.source: In the [command bar](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh465302): You should put most commands on the command bar, which helps to organize commands and makes them easy to access.
trans-unit.target: In the [command bar](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh465302): You should put most commands on the command bar, which helps to organize commands and makes them easy to access.

trans-unit.source: On the app's canvas: If the user is on a page or view that has a single purpose, you can provide commands for that purpose directly on the canvas.
trans-unit.target: On the app's canvas: If the user is on a page or view that has a single purpose, you can provide commands for that purpose directly on the canvas.

trans-unit.source: There should be very few of these commands.
trans-unit.target: There should be very few of these commands.

trans-unit.source: In a [context menu](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh465308): You can use context menus for clipboard actions (such as cut, copy, and paste), or for commands that apply to content that cannot be selected (like adding a push pin to a location on a map).
trans-unit.target: In a [context menu](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh465308): You can use context menus for clipboard actions (such as cut, copy, and paste), or for commands that apply to content that cannot be selected (like adding a push pin to a location on a map).

trans-unit.source: Here's a list of the command surfaces that Windows provides and recommendations for when to use them.
trans-unit.target: Here's a list of the command surfaces that Windows provides and recommendations for when to use them.

trans-unit.source: App canvas (content area)
trans-unit.target: App canvas (content area)

trans-unit.source: If a command is critical and is constantly needed for the user to complete the core scenarios, put it on the canvas (the content area of your app).
trans-unit.target: If a command is critical and is constantly needed for the user to complete the core scenarios, put it on the canvas (the content area of your app).

trans-unit.source: Because you can put commands near (or on) the objects they affect, putting commands on the canvas makes them easy and obvious to use.
trans-unit.target: Because you can put commands near (or on) the objects they affect, putting commands on the canvas makes them easy and obvious to use.

trans-unit.source: However, choose the commands you put on the canvas carefully.
trans-unit.target: However, choose the commands you put on the canvas carefully.

trans-unit.source: Too many commands on the app canvas takes up valuable screen space and can overwhelm the user.
trans-unit.target: Too many commands on the app canvas takes up valuable screen space and can overwhelm the user.

trans-unit.source: If the command won't be frequently used, consider putting it in another command surface, such as menu or the command bar's "More" area.
trans-unit.target: If the command won't be frequently used, consider putting it in another command surface, such as menu or the command bar's "More" area.

trans-unit.source: Command bar
trans-unit.target: Command bar

trans-unit.source: Command bars provide users with easy access to actions.
trans-unit.target: Command bars provide users with easy access to actions.

trans-unit.source: You can use a command bar to show commands or options that are specific to the user's context, such as a photo selection or drawing mode.
trans-unit.target: You can use a command bar to show commands or options that are specific to the user's context, such as a photo selection or drawing mode.

trans-unit.source: Command bars can be placed at the top of the screen, at the bottom of the screen, or at both the top and bottom of the screen.
trans-unit.target: Command bars can be placed at the top of the screen, at the bottom of the screen, or at both the top and bottom of the screen.

trans-unit.source: Menus and context menus
trans-unit.target: Menus and context menus

trans-unit.source: Sometimes it is more efficient to group multiple commands into a command menu.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes it is more efficient to group multiple commands into a command menu.

trans-unit.source: Menus let you present more options with less space.
trans-unit.target: Menus let you present more options with less space.

trans-unit.source: Menus can include interactive controls.
trans-unit.target: Menus can include interactive controls.

trans-unit.source: Context menus can provide shortcuts to commonly-used actions and provide access to secondary commands that are only relevant in certain contexts.
trans-unit.target: Context menus can provide shortcuts to commonly-used actions and provide access to secondary commands that are only relevant in certain contexts.

trans-unit.source: Context menus are for the following types of commands and command scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Context menus are for the following types of commands and command scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Contextual actions on text selections, such as Copy, Cut, Paste, Check Spelling, and so on.
trans-unit.target: Contextual actions on text selections, such as Copy, Cut, Paste, Check Spelling, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Commands for an object that needs to be acted upon but that can't be selected or otherwise indicated.
trans-unit.target: Commands for an object that needs to be acted upon but that can't be selected or otherwise indicated.

trans-unit.source: Dialog controls
trans-unit.target: Dialog controls

trans-unit.source: Dialogs are modal UI overlays that provide contextual app information.
trans-unit.target: Dialogs are modal UI overlays that provide contextual app information.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, dialogs block interactions with the app window until being explicitly dismissed, and often request some kind of action from the user.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, dialogs block interactions with the app window until being explicitly dismissed, and often request some kind of action from the user.

trans-unit.source: Dialogs can be disruptive and should only be used in certain situations.
trans-unit.target: Dialogs can be disruptive and should only be used in certain situations.

trans-unit.source: For more info, see the [When to confirm or undo actions](#whentoconfirm) section.
trans-unit.target: For more info, see the [When to confirm or undo actions](#whentoconfirm) section.

trans-unit.target: Ask the user to confirm an action without blocking interaction with the app.

trans-unit.source: When to confirm or undo actions
trans-unit.target: When to confirm or undo actions

trans-unit.source: No matter how well-designed the user interface is and no matter how careful the user is, at some point, all users will perform an action they wish they hadn't.
trans-unit.target: No matter how well-designed the user interface is and no matter how careful the user is, at some point, all users will perform an action they wish they hadn't.

trans-unit.source: Your app can help in these situations by requiring the user to confirm an action, or by providing a way of undoing recent actions.
trans-unit.target: Your app can help in these situations by requiring the user to confirm an action, or by providing a way of undoing recent actions.

trans-unit.source: For actions that can't be undone and have major consequences, we recommend using a confirmation dialog.
trans-unit.target: For actions that can't be undone and have major consequences, we recommend using a confirmation dialog.

trans-unit.source: Examples of such actions include:
trans-unit.target: Examples of such actions include:

trans-unit.source: Overwriting a file
trans-unit.target: Overwriting a file

trans-unit.source: Not saving a file before closing
trans-unit.target: Not saving a file before closing

trans-unit.source: Confirming permanent deletion of a file or data
trans-unit.target: Confirming permanent deletion of a file or data

trans-unit.source: Making a purchase (unless the user opts out of requiring a confirmation)
trans-unit.target: Making a purchase (unless the user opts out of requiring a confirmation)

trans-unit.source: Submitting a form, such as signing up for something
trans-unit.target: Submitting a form, such as signing up for something

trans-unit.source: For actions that can be undone, offering a simple undo command is usually enough.
trans-unit.target: For actions that can be undone, offering a simple undo command is usually enough.

trans-unit.source: Examples of such actions include:
trans-unit.target: Examples of such actions include:

trans-unit.source: Deleting a file
trans-unit.target: Deleting a file

trans-unit.source: Deleting an email (not permanently)
trans-unit.target: Deleting an email (not permanently)

trans-unit.source: Modifying content or editing text
trans-unit.target: Modifying content or editing text

trans-unit.source: Renaming a file
trans-unit.target: Renaming a file

trans-unit.source: **Tip** Be careful of how much your app uses confirmation dialogs; they can be very helpful when the user makes a mistake, but they are a hindrance whenever the user is trying to perform an action intentionally.
trans-unit.target: **Tip** Be careful of how much your app uses confirmation dialogs; they can be very helpful when the user makes a mistake, but they are a hindrance whenever the user is trying to perform an action intentionally.
